Introduction

Inherited platelet function disorders (IPFDs) are a group of rare genetic disorders that are characterized by impaired platelet activity.  Although some of these disorders are accompanied by thrombocytopenia (due to impaired platelet production), others are associated with a normal platelet count.  Patients typically have mucocutaneous bleeding (eg, epistaxis, petechiae) due to impaired primary hemostasis.

Normal platelet physiology



Platelets are cell fragments that initiate hemostasis following endothelial injury.  The first phase of hemostasis (primary hemostasis) involves the formation of a platelet plug (

figure 1
):



  1. Platelet adhesion:  Endothelial injury exposes connective tissue that contains von Willebrand factor (vWF), a protein that binds glycoprotein Ib (GPIb) receptors on platelets.  vWF allows platelets to adhere to the exposed connective tissue.
  2. Platelet activation and secretion:  On adhesion, platelets become activated, undergoing irreversible conformational changes that give them a spiky morphology.  In this activated state, they release a variety of mediators that amplify and reinforce the hemostatic process, including:
    • Intracellular granules:  Dense granules (eg, calcium, serotonin, ADP) recruit and directly activate additional platelets.  Alpha granules (eg, fibrinogen, factor V) contribute to the later steps in hemostasis, including generating thrombin, which further activates platelets.
    • Arachidonic acid (released from phospholipids on the plasma membrane):  This acid is converted to thromboxane A2 (TXA2), a potent inducer of platelet aggregation.
  3. Platelet aggregation:  Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa (GPIIb/IIIa) receptors on platelets undergo conformational changes to allow fibrinogen binding.  Fibrinogen cross-links adjacent platelets, allowing platelet aggregation and formation of the platelet plug.

Types of IPFDs



IPFDs occur when any of the steps of primary hemostasis (ie, platelet adhesion, activation, or aggregation) are impaired.

Impaired platelet adhesion: Bernard-Soulier syndrome



Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by mutations in the genes that encode the GPIb receptor, which is required for vWF binding and platelet adhesion.  These mutations cause platelets to have reduced adherence to vWF on exposed connective tissue at the site of endothelial injury.  Bernard-Soulier syndrome demonstrates an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance.  There are no associated syndromic features, but laboratory studies typically show mild-to-moderate thrombocytopenia with giant platelets, which may be related to GPIb having a role in regulating platelet size and number during platelet biogenesis.

Impaired platelet activation: Storage pool disorders



Storage pool disorders are characterized by impaired secretion of bioactive mediators.  Examples include:



  • Dense granule deficiency:  Results in impaired platelet activation due to deficient dense granule contents (eg, calcium, serotonin, ADP).  Platelet count is usually normal.  Dense granule deficiency is associated with certain genetic syndromes (eg, Chédiak-Higashi syndrome, in which impaired lysosomal trafficking results in oculocutaneous albinism and immunodeficiency), but it can also occur in isolation.
  • Alpha granule deficiency (ie, gray platelet syndrome):  Results in impaired platelet activation and downstream aggregation due to deficient dense alpha contents (eg, fibrinogen).  There are autosomal recessive and autosomal dominant forms, and splenomegaly is common.  A unique laboratory finding is thrombocytopenia with large, agranular, gray platelets on peripheral smear.

Defect in platelet aggregation: Glanzmann thrombasthenia



Glanzmann thrombasthenia is caused by a mutation in genes encoding the GpIIb/IIIa receptors, which are required for fibrinogen binding and platelet-platelet aggregation.  As a result, cross-links do not form between adjacent platelets.  Glanzmann thrombasthenia demonstrates an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.  There are no associated syndromic features, and platelet count is usually normal.

Clinical presentation



IPFDs present with varying degrees of mucosal (eg, epistaxis) and/or cutaneous (eg, petechiae (

image 1
), ecchymoses (
image 2
)) bleeding, findings consistent with impaired primary hemostasis (
figure 2
).  Women may report prolonged and/or heavy menstrual bleeding.  In severe cases, patients can experience life-threatening intracranial hemorrhage.  Depending on the underlying cause, additional clinical findings (eg, hypopigmentation in Chédiak-Higashi syndrome) may be present.

Diagnosis



The initial evaluation for IPFDs begins with a thorough history and physical examination, as well as laboratory studies, similar to other conditions that present with abnormal bleeding.

History and physical examination



  • Bleeding history (eg, bruising with minimal trauma, persistent bleeding, heavy menstrual bleeding) and extent of bleeding (eg, purpura on mucosal surfaces or hematuria can be signs of more extensive bleeding).
  • Family history of platelet disorders.
  • Prior platelet counts (can be used to distinguish between acute and chronic conditions).
  • Other potential contributing factors (eg, medications, recent infections, systemic symptoms).
  • Organomegaly (suggests sequestration), lymphadenopathy (suggests malignancy or infection), and syndromic features.

Laboratory evaluation



  • Complete blood count with differential:  Evaluates for thrombocytopenia, as well as red blood cell (RBC) and/or white blood cell involvement.
  • Peripheral smear:
    • Excludes laboratory error by evaluating for platelet clumps, which suggest that the thrombocytopenia is due to laboratory error.  This is particularly important when the reported platelet count is inconsistent with the clinical presentation.
    • Determines platelet size and morphology:
      • Large platelets:  Normally, platelets are about a fourth of the diameter of an RBC.  Uniformly giant platelets (ie, larger than an RBC (
        image 3
        )) are associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome.
      • Small platelets:  Uniformly small platelets are associated with Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome.
      • Gray platelets:  Gray platelets are suggestive of abnormal intracellular contents (eg, absence of granules).
  • Coagulation studies (eg, PT, activated PTT):  Are usually normal in isolated IPFDs.


If IPFD is suspected, further evaluation involves platelet function testing (ie, platelet aggregometry).

Platelet function testing



Platelet aggregometry is the gold standard for diagnosing platelet function disorders.  This assay involves testing platelet aggregation after exposure to a panel of specific platelet agonists; the pattern of platelet response determines the type of IPFD.  Patients with findings of an IPFD require repeat testing to exclude false-positive findings.



If platelet aggregometry is not readily available, the platelet function analyzer-100 can serve as a rapid screening tool for platelet function disorders.  It measures closure time (ie, the interval required for platelets to occlude a small aperture coated with agonists) to evaluate platelet aggregation.



Definitive diagnosis of an IPFD may be obtained via genetic testing.

Management

Bleeding risk reduction



  • Medication restrictions:  Drugs that can further affect platelet function (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) should be avoided.
  • Activity restrictions:  Contact sports and other activities that increase the risk of injury should be avoided in patients with significant bleeding risk.
  • Hormonal contraceptives:  Menses is suppressed by hormonal contraceptives.

Bleeding episode management



  • Desmopressin (DDAVP):  This synthetic analogue of antidiuretic hormone induces secretion of vWF from endothelial storage sites, causing a rapid and transient increase in vWF to improve platelet procoagulant function.  In Bernard-Soulier syndrome caused by impaired adhesion with vWF, desmopressin can have some benefits, possibly related to its ability to increase factor VIII levels (secondary hemostasis).
  • Antifibrinolytic agents (eg, tranexamic acid):  An antifibrinolytic agent can be administered as an adjunct to stabilize clots on mucosal surfaces (eg, for dental bleeding, epistaxis, and menstrual bleeding) that normally have increased fibrinolytic activity.
  • Thrombopoietin receptor agonists:  Thrombopoietin receptor agonists can be used to increase the platelet count in IPFDs associated with thrombocytopenia (eg, Bernard-Soulier syndrome).
  • Recombinant factor VIIa:  This factor can activate late steps in the coagulation cascade and can be used to manage bleeding in certain IPFDs (eg, Glanzmann thrombasthenia).  However, it causes an increased risk of thromboembolism.
  • Transfusion:  Due to the short lifespan of platelets and the increased risk of autoantibody formation with frequent exposure, platelet transfusions should be considered only for serious bleeding.  Indications to transfuse include:
    • Preoperative planning:  Platelet count should be >50,000/mm3 for minor procedures (eg, skin biopsy) and >100,000/mm3 for high-risk procedures (eg, neurosurgery).
    • Preventing spontaneous hemorrhage in a high-risk patient (eg, bone marrow suppression from recent chemotherapy).
    • Significant active bleeding.


Curative therapy with a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation may be considered but is typically reserved for more severe cases due to the risks of the procedure (eg, Glanzmann thrombasthenia with refractory bleeding).

Summary



Inherited platelet function disorders are a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by impaired platelet activity.  Although some of these disorders are also accompanied by thrombocytopenia (eg, due to impaired platelet production), others are associated with a normal platelet count.  Patients typically have mucocutaneous bleeding (eg, epistaxis, petechiae) due to impaired primary hemostasis.  Platelet function can be assessed via platelet function testing (eg, platelet aggregometry), and the diagnosis can be confirmed via genetic analysis.  Management is mostly supportive, with platelet transfusion reserved for severe bleeding or surgical settings.
